comment: described morality in a different context

diff.*:
Line 119: Line 119:      
The Bible claims its morality is based on spiritual joy. Jesus says He commands people to love because that is what brings joy.<sup>John 15:11</sup> The Apostles Paul and John likewise state their purpose is to help people's joy.<sup>II Cor. 1:24, I John 1:4</sup> The Bible also claims God is good because His divine commands are reasonable; they are meant to fill us with joy.<sup>Isa. 1:18</sup> Furthermore it claims God works within us making us want to do what is moral.<sup>Phil. 2:13</sup> The Bible's New Testament covenant for eternal life demands following the moral code written into our minds,<sup>Heb. 10:16</sup> which is also known as the voice of Jesus,<sup>John 10:27</sup> and the human conscience.<sup>I Pet. 3:21</sup> The Biblical morality gives rise to the often accurate saying, "When I do good I feel good, when I do bad I feel bad."
 
The Bible claims its morality is based on spiritual joy. Jesus says He commands people to love because that is what brings joy.<sup>John 15:11</sup> The Apostles Paul and John likewise state their purpose is to help people's joy.<sup>II Cor. 1:24, I John 1:4</sup> The Bible also claims God is good because His divine commands are reasonable; they are meant to fill us with joy.<sup>Isa. 1:18</sup> Furthermore it claims God works within us making us want to do what is moral.<sup>Phil. 2:13</sup> The Bible's New Testament covenant for eternal life demands following the moral code written into our minds,<sup>Heb. 10:16</sup> which is also known as the voice of Jesus,<sup>John 10:27</sup> and the human conscience.<sup>I Pet. 3:21</sup> The Biblical morality gives rise to the often accurate saying, "When I do good I feel good, when I do bad I feel bad."
−
+
Also, in theory, eating an animals feces in respect to the certain species of animal, is defined as "morality" in a different context.
